TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE a prosecutor at ORG instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant . He was suspected of being an accomplice to the offence of demanding and obtaining a ransom of MONEY for returning the stolen car of a certain PERSON
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was charged on CARDINAL counts , including blackmail ( turto prievartavimas ) and inciting the victim ( poveikis nukentėjusiajam ) to make false statements .

CARDINAL . The pre - trial investigation in the case was conducted by prosecutors at ORG . It was concluded on DATE . From that date until DATE the applicant and his counsel were given access to the case file .

CARDINAL . After having access to the case file , the applicant and his counsel requested the prosecution to discontinue the case , arguing that the charges against the applicant were ill - founded and that the case file “ contained no evidence [ of his ] guilt ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE a prosecutor of ORG dismissed the applicant 's requests . In his decision the prosecutor stated , inter alia :

“ After having access to the case file , [ the applicant ] ... submitted [ requests ] to discontinue the criminal case on the ground that he had not committed the offences alleged ... and that his guilt ... had not been proved [ kaltė ... neįrodyta ] . [ These ] allegations must be dismissed as ill - founded because it has been established [ kaltė ... įrodyta ] from the evidence collected in the course of the pre - trial investigation that the applicant is guilty of [ these ] crimes .

Although ORG has not admitted having committed the alleged offences , his guilt has been proved by the witnesses ' evidence , ... video and audio records ... and other material collected in the course of the pre - trial investigation . The fact that PERSON concealed an offence ... is proved by the evidence [ given by witnesses PERSON , GPE and GPE ] ... The fact that PERSON threatened [ the victim PERSON ] by force to obtain property ... is proved by the evidence [ given by ORG and the material evidence ] ... The fact that PERSON conspired with persons who had committed the theft [ of the car ] ... is proved by [ his own statements ] ... The fact that ORG ... intimidated the victim is fully proved by the evidence [ given by PERSON , ORG and material evidence ] ... [ The above evidence ] is assessed by the prosecution as an incitement to make [ PERSON ] give false statements ...
Against the above background , in accordance with LAW , it is decided
CARDINAL . NORP to dismiss [ the applicant 's ] requests entirely , and
CARDINAL . NORP to inform the persons concerned about the decision . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG at ORG confirmed the bill of indictment and sent the case to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG transmitted the case to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE a judge of ORG committed the applicant for trial .

CARDINAL . On DATE the judge found the applicant guilty of blackmail and inciting the victim to make false statements . He was convicted as the principal offender on the blackmail charge . He was acquitted on CARDINAL other counts . The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . He was also fined CARDINAL litai and his property was confiscated .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , relying on various errors of domestic substantive and procedural law . He pleaded , inter alia , that he had been presumed guilty and that he had been deprived of a fair trial by an independent and impartial court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a full appeal hearing . It amended the judgment of CARDINAL DATE in so far as it concerned the applicant 's conviction for blackmail , ruling that the applicant was a secondary party , not the principal offender . The sentence remained unchanged .
CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal with ORG , pleading that both lower courts had erred in fact and law and that he had not committed the alleged offences .

CARDINAL . On DATE the judge of ORG who had delivered the first - instance judgment wrote a letter to the President of ORG in which he contested the conclusions reached by ORG as to the level of the applicant 's participation in the blackmail offence . In that letter the judge maintained that the applicant ought to have been convicted as the principal offender . The judge requested the President to lodge a petition ( kasacinis teikimas ) to quash ORG judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG lodged a petition with ORG to quash ORG judgment . In the petition the President stated , inter alia :

“ The judgment of ORG should be quashed ... [ The appellate court ] ... wrongly interpreted and applied the law ... On the basis of the material ... it established that PERSON ... executed the will of the group of persons ... and was the principal offender on the blackmail charge ...
In accordance with LAW , I petition
to quash the judgment of ORG of DATE ... and to uphold the judgment of ORG of DATE . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the same President of ORG appointed a judge rapporteur in the case . On CARDINAL DATE the President also appointed a ORG of CARDINAL judges of ORG to examine the case .

CARDINAL . A hearing was held on DATE during which ORG requested the ORG to uphold the petition on behalf of the prosecution , which had not lodged an appeal itself in the case . The applicant requested ORG to uphold his appeal and reject the petition .

CARDINAL . On the above date ORG quashed the judgment of ORG and upheld the judgment of ORG , rejecting the applicant 's appeal and upholding the petition . ORG found that the applicant had been the principal offender on the blackmail charge .
CARDINAL . Relevant provisions are as follows :

“ In administering justice in criminal matters judges are independent and beholden only to the law . Judges decide criminal cases in accordance with the law and their conscience in conditions which make it impossible for them to be affected by outside matters . Any interference with the judges ' or courts ' actions in administering justice is prohibited and gives rise to liability under the law . ”
No evidence shall have a prejudicial influence on a court ... ”

Under the terms of LAW judge in respect of whom there are lawful grounds to fear a lack of impartiality must withdraw . On the same ground the judge can be challenged by the defendant and other parties to the case .
Under LAW of LAW and LAW , ORG is composed of the President , Presidents of ORG and other judges .
Under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW and Articles DATE , judges of ORG are professional and permanent judges appointed by ORG .

According to section DATE of LAW , presidents of divisions are officers having power over the “ organisational sphere ” of the courts ' work . Under the third paragraph of section CARDINAL , presidents of divisions may also sit as judges ; in such cases they perform the same judicial functions as ordinary judges .
LAW provides that the President of ORG ,
“ ( CARDINAL ) in examining cases , has the same rights and obligations as other judges . [ He ] may submit petitions to quash or amend a lower court 's judgment ... ;
( CARDINAL ) constitutes chambers of judges and appoints their presidents , ... distributes cases among judges ... [ and ] supervises their examination ;
( CARDINAL ) NORP submits proposals to the President of the Court on premiums and bonuses for judges and other officials ;
( CARDINAL ) heads the Registry ;
( CARDINAL ) organises the case - law research work ... ;
( CARDINAL ) confirms the statistical survey of activities ... ;
( CARDINAL ) executes other functions under the law and the organisational directives of the President of ORG . ”
LAW provides that the President of ORG is responsible for the organisation of appeal hearings .

The fourth paragraph of section CARDINAL of LAW effectively prohibits presidents of courts or presidents of divisions from exerting any influence over or otherwise breaching the independence of other judges in their administration of justice .

Under LAW of the ORG the President of ORG , the President of ORG , presidents of regional courts , and presidents of the criminal divisions of the above courts may submit a petition to quash or amend a particular lower court 's judgment . According to LAW the court hearing the petition shall follow the same procedure as on a normal appeal lodged by the parties to the proceedings .

LAW lays down the requirements for lodging an appeal or petition : it should refer to the specific court hearing the appeal , the case and decision at issue , the substance of the decision and the grounds for quashing the lower court 's judgment .
LAW provides :
“ A person shall be considered innocent until proved guilty in accordance with law by a final judgment of the court . ”
LAW of the ORG provides :
“ No one shall be declared guilty of having committed an offence or punished by a criminal penalty save by a court judgment in accordance with law . ”
Article CARDINAL of the LAW provides that prosecutors conduct , inter alia , criminal prosecutions and supervise those responsible for the pre - trial investigation .

Under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG the prosecutor 's role is to ensure that the criminal case is instituted lawfully and that the domestic law is complied with during the pre - trial investigation , to press charges at trial , to appeal against any procedural act and to supervise the execution of judgments .
In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG gave , inter alia , the following description of the general role of a prosecutor in the NORP criminal process :
“ The LAW treats prosecutors as part of the judiciary having specific functions . A prosecutor is an officer who supervises the pre - trial investigation ...

The prosecutor can take part in the criminal case right from the outset . ... In accordance with the procedure provided for by law , he commences the criminal prosecution and pursues it by investigating the crime . CARDINAL of his functions is to supervise the authorities conducting the pre - trial investigation . ... The prosecutor can himself conduct the investigation of any offence . ...
The prosecutor is therefore responsible for the pre - trial stage of the criminal proceedings . ...
The law does not provide the court ... [ but ] the prosecutor with the procedural means to supervise the pre - trial investigation . ”

Under Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL to CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG , an investigator , prosecutor and court are all entitled to institute or discontinue a criminal case and to collect evidence in the case ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . These functions are exercised according to the stage of the proceedings .
The pre - trial investigation can be conducted by prosecutors working under the authority of ORG , or investigators working for ORG ( Article CARDINAL ) .

Pursuant to ORG and CARDINAL of the ORG the prosecutors ensure that domestic law is complied with by the investigators at the stage of the pre - trial investigation . They are responsible for rectifying any breaches of the law . In doing so , the prosecutors “ function independently from other authorities and are beholden only to the law ” ( LAW and CARDINAL ) . Under LAW the prosecutors ' decisions are “ binding on all authorities and persons ” .

Where the pre - trial investigation is conducted by the prosecution , an accused may , while having access to the case file ( Articles CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the ORG ) , request the prosecutor to “ supplement the investigation ” . The prosecutor must give a reasoned decision if he dismisses this request ( LAW ) . After such a decision , the bill of indictment may be prepared LAW .

A complaint by the accused about an act of the prosecutor at the stage of the pre - trial investigation shall be submitted to and determined by a higher prosecutor ( Articles CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the ORG ) .

After the bill of indictment is confirmed , the case must be transmitted to a court ( LAW . From that stage on “ any requests or complaints about the case shall be submitted directly to the court ” ( LAW ) .
